Sorry but this is a very flawed analysis.

The democratic process in Israel yielded an intransigent rightist government that reflects the will of the people.

Similarly, democracy in Arab countries will give rise to governments that reflect the will of the people. Be careful what you wish for, as you probably don't want to know the long-ignored Arab public opinion on this conflict. This is probably the only issue where there is little divergence in opinion amongst the entire spectrum of Arab society. Under the best of circumstances, Israel will be expected to provide major concessions in any future peace deal and current offers including rescinding the Palestinian right of return could be taken off the table.

Likud is shortsighted by not pursuing a deal under the false pretense of lack of a peace partner. It should cease settlement construction and aggressively pursue an agreement on the best terms it could ever get, as the window to do so may close.

Or maybe that's what it wants. After all, any negotiated deal with Palestinians would upend settlers' aspirations of implementing their projects in Judea and Samaria.

Noor -- Well said.

Democracy does make possible a real peace that is legitimated by the acceptance of the whole people in a democratic choice. However, it must be peace terms they will vote to accept and ratify.

The dream terms of the Israeli right wing are not a peace that can be accepted or ratified in such a democratic process. What the Israeli right wing now thinks of as terms for a deal are fantasy in that setting.

The Israelis will never get better terms than they could get today.

People would democratically accept terms already made to keep peace. That is different from accepting and ratifying those same terms as their own later, when they emerge from their current troubles stronger, and face the initial choice rather than fait accompli and overturning peace already in hand.

Israel's strongest moment is now. The best terms Israel can get now are the best they will ever get. What they won't do now, they won't have the choice to do later.

...And it was not just painters who lost their life's work. There were musicians whose places were completely destroyed. Case in point, Tony Moreno and Bruce Arnold had a recording and rehearsal studio that was completely wiped out. Vintage amps, guitars, top of the line recording equipment, grand piano, drumsets, hard drives with years of music on them and irreplaceable manuscripts: all gone. That studio was an unsung piece of New York's music history.
From the Lounge Lizards to the whole jazz-scene in New York and abroad, it was a place to rehearse, experiment and record.
My own paintings were on the walls and even after repeated washings (off the stretchers) they still stink of the heating oil that got into the mixture of saltwater and sewage that flooded the place.
It was a truly toxic mix, and some of the other people who deserve some props are the maintenance people who risked their own health (and one in particular who almost drowned when the water came in)
trying to clear the place out prior to letting the stunned artists back in.

I believe Israel is playing a substantial role in that proxy war, as it does in all American actions on Israeli borders affecting Israeli security. Re: HADCRUT vs BEST

Both sets of data have their drawbacks ("urban heat island" NOT being one of them), but if one's purpose is to analyse the effect of CO2 on the atmosphere, it might make more sense to use data solely involving atmospheric temperatures (BEST), as opposed to being a hybrid of air temperatures and surface seawater temperatures (HADCRUT). Global ocean temperatures will experience a severe lag that muddies the signal of how hot the AIR is getting.

Interesting to note that while BEST is almost always warmer than HADCRUT, the trends within the data mimic each other until the final temperature surge that started in the 1970s:

http://www.woodfortrees.org/plot/hadcrut3vgl/from:1850/to:2012/mean:60/p...

And to repeat, the whole point of BEST was to make sure there was no urban heat island effect contaminating the data. So the higher temps are not an artifact of sloppy science.

(My thanks to arty for finally piquing my curiosity enough to investigate what woodfortrees has to offer.)

Far better to read your link ... which allows for 2.7F warming by 2100 and allows the assumptions about past warming to stand with little challenge.

The answers there are far more balanced than you suggest in your post, and probably overstate warming by a material margin.

No, how about "Aesop's Fables,"  "Crime and Punishment," "The Trial," "1984," or "Animal Farm," just to name some of the most obvious examples.
